      6. 6
        (a) Karmakar, T. K., Ghosh, B. K., Usman, A., Fun, H. K., Rivière, E., Mallah, T., Aromì, G., and Chandra, S. K. Inorg. Chem.2005 44 2391 2399
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6a
        Magneto-Structural Correlations: Synthesis of a Family of End-On Azido-Bridged Manganese(II) Dinuclear Compounds with S = 5 Spin Ground State
        Karmakar, Tapan K.; Ghosh, Barindra K.; Usman, A.; Fun, Hoong-Kun; Riviere, Eric; Mallah, Talal; Aromi, Guillem; Chandra, Swapan K.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (7), 2391-2399CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The prepn. of multidentate pyridyl-imine ligands, L1-L3, and their reactivity with the MnII/N3- system is described (L1 = [N,N-bis(pyridine-2-yl)benzylidene]ethane-1,2-diamine; L2 = [N,N-bis(pyridine-2-yl)benzylidene]propane-1,3-diamine, and L3 = [N,N-bis(pyridine-2-yl)benzylidene]butane-1,4-diamine). Complexes comprising dinuclear end-on bis(μ-azido)-bridged Mn(II) units [Mn2(L1)2(N3)4][Mn2(L1)2(N3)2(MeOH)2](ClO4)2 (two cocrystd. dinuclear units, 1·2), [Mn2(L2)2(N3)2](ClO4)2 (3), and [Mn2(L3)2(N3)2](ClO4)2 (4) were synthesized. The crystal structures of 1-4 as well as their magnetic properties are presented. Each Mn atom of cocrystd. complexes in 1·2 is heptacoordinated, displaying Mn-N-Mn angles, θ, of 102.53(12) and 101.70(12)° and Mn···Mn distances of 3.5091(7) and 3.4680(7) Å. However, each Mn center in compds. 3 and 4 is located within an octahedral coordination environment, the complexes displaying θ angles of 104.29(11) and 103.60(18)°, resp., and Mn···Mn vectors of 3.5371(7) and 3.5338(10) Å, resp. Magnetic susceptibility studies revealed intramol. ferromagnetic superexchange, yielding an S = 5 spin ground state in all complexes. Fitting of the exptl. data led to coupling consts., intermol. exchange values, and g factors (in the J/zJ'/g format) of 0.77 cm-1/0.01 cm-1/2.20 (1·2), 2.04 cm-1/0.01 cm-1/1.99(3), and 1.75 cm-1/-0.05 cm-1/2.04(4), resp. (using H = -2JS1S2 as the convention for the Heisenberg spin-Hamiltonian). These results are consistent with predictions from recent DFT calcns. performed on end-on bis(μ-N3-)-bridged MnII dinuclear complexes. A plot of exptl. J vs. θ, including data from the only preexisting compd. of this kind, reveals a linear relation, which could be the 1st evidence of a possible magneto-structural correlation between these two parameters.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXhsF2ntb4%253D&md5=ee20857eddb6e0d60273aca3021985b4
        (b) Du, M., Bu, X. H., Guo, Y. M., and Ribas, J. Chem.—Eur. J.2004 10 1345 1354
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        6b
        Ligand design for alkali-metal-templated self-assembly of unique high-nuclearity CuII aggregates with diverse coordination cage units: crystal structures and properties
        Du, Miao; Bu, Xian-He; Guo, Ya-Mei; Ribas, Joan
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2004), 10 (6), 1345-1354CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        The construction of two unique, high-nuclearity CuII supramol. aggregates with tetrahedral or octahedral cage units, {(μ3-Cl)[Li⊂Cu4(μ-L1)3]3}(ClO4)8(H2O)4.5 (1) and {[Na2⊂Cu12(μ-L2)8(μ-Cl)4](ClO4)8(H2O)10(H3O+)2}∞ (2) by alkali-metal-templated (Li+ or Na+) self-assembly, was achieved using two newly designed carboxylic-functionalized diazamesocyclic ligands, N,N'-bis(3-propionyloxy)-1,4-diazacycloheptane (H2L1) or 1,5-diazacyclooctane-N,N'-diacetate acid (H2L2). Complex 1 crystallizes in the trigonal space group ‾R3c (a = b 20.866(3), c 126.26(4) Å and Z = 12), and 2 in the triclinic P‾1 space group (a 13.632(4), b 14.754(4), c 19.517(6) Å, α 99.836(6), β 95.793(5), γ 116.124(5)° and Z = 1). By subtle variation of the ligand structures and the alkali-metal templates, different polymeric motifs were obtained: a dodecanuclear architecture 1 consisting of three Cu4 tetrahedral cage units with a Li+ template, and a supramol. chain 2 consisting of two crystallog. nonequivalent octahedral Cu6 polyhedra with a Na+ template. The effects of ligand functionality and alkali metal template ions on the self-assembly processes of both coordination supramol. aggregates, and their magnetic behaviors are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXivVykt7w%253D&md5=ba2bd667859c09a266635da7afe56aef

        (a) Li, M., Xiang, J. F., Yuan, L. J., Wu, S. M., Chen, S. P., and Sun, J. T. Cryst. Growth Des.2006 6 2036 2040

        7a
        Syntheses, Structures, and Photoluminescence of Three Novel Coordination Polymers Constructed from Dimeric d10 Metal Units
        Li, Ming; Xiang, Jiangfeng; Yuan, Liangjie; Wu, Simin; Chen, Shuoping; Sun, Jutang
        Crystal Growth & Design (2006), 6 (9), 2036-2040CODEN: CGDEFU; ISSN:1528-7483. (American Chemical Society)
        Three novel coordination polymers contg. dimeric d10 metal units, [Cd(2,3-Pydc)(H2O)2]n (1), [Zn(2,3-Pydc)(H2O)2]n (2), and {[La2Zn3(2,3-Pydc)6(H2O)6]·4H2O}n (3), were synthesized by hydrothermal reaction of pyridine-2,3-dicarboxylic acid (2,3-Pydc) with d10 metal oxides at a suitable temp. Complex 1 is a 1-dimensional (1D) ladder coordination polymer contg. a dimeric Cd2O8N2 unit. Complex 2 forms a two-dimensional (2D) layer built from a unique Zn2O8N2 unit, in which each pair of Zn(II) ions are bridged by two water mols. Complex 3 is a 2-dimensional heterometallic framework by 1-dimensional chain linked by Zn(2,3-Pydc) units, where the 1-dimensional chain is constructed via dimeric La2O16 units. The photoluminescent studies show that complex 2 shows an emission at 417 nm (λex = 363 nm).
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        7b
        A blue luminescent star-shaped ZnII complex that can detect benzene
        Pang, Jun; Marcotte, Eric J.-P.; Seward, Corey; Brown, R. Stephen; Wang, Suning
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2001), 40 (21), 4042-4045CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        The authors synthesized a new class of blue luminescent org. star-shaped mols.-that contain either 7-azaindolyl or 2,2'-dipyridylamino groups. Some of the new star-shaped mols. have been found to be promising blue emitters in electroluminescence devices. Most interestingly, the authors found that the new star-shaped mols. are capable of coordinating to various metal centers, which results in the formation of novel coordination compds. Some of these new compds. are capable of selectively detecting specific small mols. by functioning as fluorescent sensors, an example of which, the ZnII complex of 1,3,5-tris[p-(2,2'-dipyridylamino)phenyl]benzene (TPDPB, I) is described herein. The TPDPB ligand displays a broad emission band at λmax = 386 nm in soln. (CH2Cl2) and at λmax = 400 nm in the solid state when irradiated by UV light. The quantum efficiency of TPDPB in soln. was detd. to be 0.19. relative to that of 9.10-diphenylanthracence. The star-shaped complex, [(ZnCl2)3(TPDPB)] (1) was obtained from the reaction of TPDPB with three equiv. of ZnCl2 in CH2Cl2/CH3OH soln. Complex I1 is stable toward air and moisture in soln. and in the solid state and its fluorescence emission shows an unusually high selectivity to benzene vapor.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3MXosV2jt7w%253D&md5=7d76ff225d005d97f3fbd6cf9e93fdf3
        (c) Zheng, S. L., Yang, J. H., Yu, X. L., Chen, X. M., and Wong, W. T. Inorg. Chem.2004 43 830 838
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        7c
        Syntheses, Structures, Photoluminescence, and Theoretical Studies of d10 Metal Complexes of 2,2'-Dihydroxy-[1,1']binaphthalenyl-3,3'-dicarboxylate
        Zheng, Shao-Liang; Yang, Jin-Hua; Yu, Xiao-Lan; Chen, Xiao-Ming; Wong, Wing-Tak
        Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (2), 830-838CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The free solvated ligand, H2bna·MeOH·H2O (1), and its dimeric complex, [Cd2(bna)2(H2O)6] (2) (bna = 2,2'-dihydroxy-[1,1']-binaphthalene-3,3'-dicarboxylate), were obtained by evapn. of the solns., while two new d10 metal-hydroxy cluster-based coordination polymers, [Cd8(OH)4(H2O)10(bna)6]·17H2O (3) and [Hpy]2[Zn4(OH)2(H2O)2(bna)4]·2H2O·2MeCN (4), were obtained by a hydrothermal route. All the compds. were characterized by x-ray crystallog. and photoluminescence measurements. Compd. 1 consists of a three-dimensional, H-bonded supramol. array, 2 exhibits a dimeric mol. featuring a square motif organized by two Cd(II) atoms and two bna ligands each at the corner, and 3 contains unprecedented [Cd8(μ3-OH)2(μ-OH)2(μ-H2O)2]12+ octanuclear metallacrown cores which are interlinked through bna to afford a two-dimensional structure, while 4 features layers with butterfly-shaped [Zn4(μ3-OH)2]6+ clusters. All the complexes display photoluminescent properties in the blue/green range. The manifestation of photoluminescence, as probed by MO calcns. performed on the complexes and also on hypothetical multinuclear complexes, is attributed to a ligand-to-metal charge-transfer mechanism. In addn. to presenting a new approach for the study of the photoluminescent properties of metal-cluster-based coordination polymers by using simple model compds., the study also reveals the dominant role of the structure of the ligand over that of the d10 metal-hydroxy (or oxy) cluster and the presence of the cluster significantly increasing the emission lifetime.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        7d
        Synthesis, Structure, and Luminescent Property of a Heterometallic Metal-Organic Framework Constructed from Rod-Shaped Secondary Building Blocks
        He, Jianghua; Yu, Jihong; Zhang, Yuetao; Pan, Qinhe; Xu, Ruren
        Inorganic Chemistry (2005), 44 (25), 9279-9282CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A new heterometallic MOF compd., [ZnNa(m-BDC)2]·NH2Me2 (MOF-CJ2; m-BDC = 1,3-benzenedicarboxylate), was solvothermally synthesized and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, x-ray powder diffraction, ICP, TGA, IR, and photoluminescence spectroscopy analyses. It crystallizes in monoclinic space group C2/c with a 13.277(6), b 14.323(7), c 11.328(6) Å, and β 111.73(2)°. Its framework is constructed from M-O-C (M = Na and Zn) rods composed of alternating six-coordinated Na(I) centers and four-coordinated Zn(II) centers. These rods are linked by m-BDC links to form primitive cubic (pcu) type rod packing. This framework exemplifies the 1st open-framework heterometallic MOF structure based on the assembly of infinite rod building units.

        7e
        Supramolecular organisation of polymeric coordination chains into a three-dimensional network with nanosized channels that clathrate large organic molecules
        Zhang, Xian-Ming; Tong, Ming-Liang; Gong, Meng-Lian; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2003), (1), 138-142CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Hydrothermal treatment of a mixt. of [Zn(MeCO2)2]·H2O, terephthalic acid, and 2,2'-bipyridine resulted in a coordination polymer [Zn(bpy)(tp)](bpy) (1; bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine, H2tp = terephthalic acid) which crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, Mr = 541.85, a 15.388(11), b 21.963(11), c 7.670(8) Å, β 112.82(2)°, Z = 4, dc = 1.506 g cm-3. An x-ray single-crystal structural anal. reveals that 1 is a three-dimensional network with nanosized channels constructed from 1-dimensional coordination chains via C-H...O hydrogen bonds and arom. intercalations. TGA and XRPD showed that the porous network of 1 is very stable while the guest 2,2'-bipyridine mols. in the channels are removable. Compd. 1 shows a strong ligand-centered emission at room temp. in the solid state.

      8. 8
        (a) Bauer, C. A., Timofeeva, T. V., Settersten, T. B., Patterson, B. D., Liu, V. H., Simmons, B. A., and Allendorf, M. D. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2007 129 7136 7144
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8a
        Influence of Connectivity and Porosity on Ligand-Based Luminescence in Zinc Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Bauer, Christina A.; Timofeeva, Tatiana V.; Settersten, Thomas B.; Patterson, Brian D.; Liu, Vincent H.; Simmons, Blake A.; Allendorf, Mark D.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (22), 7136-7144CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Applications of metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) require close correlation between their structure and function. The authors describe the prepn. and characterization of two Zn MOFs based on a flexible and emissive linker mol., stilbene, which retains its luminescence within these solid materials. Reaction of trans-4,4'-stilbenedicarboxylic acid (H2L) and zinc nitrate in DMF yielded a dense 2-dimensional network, Zn3L3(DMF)2 (1), featuring Zn in both octahedral and tetrahedral coordination environments connected by trans-stilbene links. Similar reaction in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) at higher temps., followed by replacement of solvent in workup, resulted in a porous, 3-dimensional framework structure, Zn4OL3·(DMF)(CHCl3) (2). This framework consists of two interpenetrating cubic lattices, each featuring basic Zn carboxylate vertexes joined by trans-stilbene, analogous to the isoreticular MOF (IRMOF) series. The optical properties of both 1 and 2 correlate with the local ligand environments obsd. in the crystal structures. Steady-state and time-resolved spectroscopic measurements reveal that the stilbene linkers in the dense structure 1 exhibit a small degree of interchromophore coupling. In contrast, the stilbenoid units in 2 display very little interaction in this low-d. 3-dimensional framework, with excitation and emission spectra characteristic of monomeric stilbenes, similar to the dicarboxylic acid in dil. soln. In both cases, the rigidity of the stilbene linker increases upon coordination to the inorg. units through inhibition of torsion about the central ethylene bond, resulting in luminescent crystals with increased emission lifetimes compared to solns. of trans-stilbene. The emission spectrum of 2 depends on the nature of the incorporated solvent mols., suggesting use of this or related materials in sensor applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2sXltlWlurs%253D&md5=d4fb4e7121ad3251fba2c481c1ca2c49
        (b) Fang, Q. R., Zhu, G. S., Jin, Z., Ji, Y. Y., Ye, J. W., Xue, M., Yang, H., Wang, Y., and Qiu, S. L. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.2007 46 6638 6642
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        8b
        Mesoporous metal-organic framework with rare etb topology for hydrogen storage and dye assembly
        Fang, Qian-Rong; Zhu, Guang-Shan; Jin, Zhao; Ji, Yan-Yan; Ye, Jun-Wei; Xue, Ming; Yang, Hua; Wang, Yue; Qiu, Shi-Lun
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2007), 46 (35), 6638-6642CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A new mesoporous metal-org. framework (MOF), [Cd3(bpdc)3(DMF)].5DMF.18H2O (H2bpdc = 4,4'-biphenyldicarboxylic acid), with the largest reported 1D hexagonal nanotube-like channels of 24.5 Å x 27.9 Å and rare etb topol. was synthesized. It exhibits good fluorescence properties and substantial H uptake. For the first time, the compd. was assembled with Rh6G dye mols., and the product showed favorable temp.-dependent luminescent properties.

        (a) Kondo, M., Okubo, T., Asami, A., Noro, S. I., Yoshitomi, T., Kitagawa, S., Ishii, T., and Matsuzaka, H. Agnew. Chem., Int. Ed.1999 38 140 143
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9a
        Rational synthesis of stable channel-like cavities with methane gas adsorption properties: [{Cu2(pzdc)2(L)}n] (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate; L =a pillar ligand)
        Kondo, Mitsuru; Okubo, Takashi; Asami, Akiko; Noro, Shin-Ichiro; Yoshitomi, Tomomichi; Kitagawa, Susumu; Ishii, Tomohiko; Matsuzaka, Hiroyuki; Seki, Kenji
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (1999), 38 (1/2), 140-143CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Porous coordination networks were designed in prepd. copper complexes [{Cu2(pzdc)2(L)}n] (pzdc = pyrazine-2,3-dicarboxylate; L = pillar ligand pyrazine, 4,4'-bipyridyl, N-4-pyridinyl-4-pyridinecarboxamide). The structure of [{Cu2(pzdc)2(pyz)}.2H2O]n (1) was detd. by x-ray crystallog. The complex consists of a pillared layer structure with a two-dimensional sheet of [Cu(pzdc)2]n and pillar pyrazine ligands that bridge each sheet. The channels are occupied by water mols. Thermal dehydration of 1 at 100-260° resulted in a stable phase which retained the porous network without decompn. (powder XRD study). Methane adsorption capabilities of the coordination networks were studied. Increased methane absorption activity for pillar ligands 4,4'-bipyridyl and N-4-pyridinyl-4-pyridinecarboxamide is consistent with the larger channel sizes of these complexes. The activity is comparable to that of zeolites and other reported stable porous coordination networks.

        9b
        Functional porous coordination polymers
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXktFShtLk%253D&md5=9df52e99bad3cc0db67f65551a8c154f
        (c) Matsuda, R., Kitaura, R., Kitagawa, S., Kubota, Y., Belosludov, R. U., Kobayashi, T. C., Sakamoto, H., Chiba, T., Takata, M., Kawazoe, Y., and Mita, Y. Nature2005 436 238 241
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        9c
        Highly controlled acetylene accommodation in a metal-organic microporous material
        Matsuda, Ryotaro; Kitaura, Ryo; Kitagawa, Susumu; Kubota, Yoshiki; Belosludov, Rodion V.; Kobayashi, Tatsuo C.; Sakamoto, Hirotoshi; Chiba, Takashi; Takata, Masaki; Kawazoe, Yoshiyuki; Mita, Yoshimi
        Nature (London, United Kingdom) (2005), 436 (7048), 238-241CODEN: NATUAS; ISSN:0028-0836. (Nature Publishing Group)
        Metal-org. microporous materials (MOMs) have attracted wide scientific attention owing to their unusual structure and properties, as well as com. interest due to their potential applications in storage, sepn. and heterogeneous catalysis. One of the advantages of MOMs compared to other microporous materials, such as activated carbons, is their ability to exhibit a variety of pore surface properties such as hydrophilicity and chirality, as a result of the controlled incorporation of org. functional groups into the pore walls. This capability means that the pore surfaces of MOMs could be designed to adsorb specific mols.; but few design strategies for the adsorption of small mols. have been established so far. Here we report high levels of selective sorption of acetylene mols. as compared to a very similar mol., carbon dioxide, onto the functionalized surface of a MOM. The acetylene mols. are held at a periodic distance from one another by hydrogen bonding between two non-coordinated oxygen atoms in the nanoscale pore wall of the MOM and the two hydrogen atoms of the acetylene mol. This permits the stable storage of acetylene at a d. 200 times the safe compression limit of free acetylene at room temp.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXmtVers7o%253D&md5=33d1004f5e9fc5dff5fe8327ebc502d7

        (a) Rosi, N. L., Eckert, J., Eddaoudi, M., Vodak, D. J., Kim, J., O’Keeffe, M., and Yaghi, O. M. Science2003 300 1127 1129

        10a
        Hydrogen Storage in Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Rosi, Nathaniel L.; Eckert, Juergen; Eddaoudi, Mohamed; Vodak, David T.; Kim, Jaheon; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2003), 300 (5622), 1127-1130CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Metal-org. framework-5 (MOF-5) Zn4O(BDC)3 (BDC = 1,4-benzenedicarboxylate) with a cubic three-dimensional extended porous structure adsorbed hydrogen up to 4.5 wt.% (17.2 hydrogen mols. per formula unit) at 78 K and 1.0 wt.% at room temp. and pressure of 20 bar. Inelastic neutron scattering spectroscopy of the rotational transitions of the adsorbed hydrogen mols. indicates two well-defined binding sites (termed I and II), which the authors assoc. with hydrogen binding to zinc and the BDC linker, resp. Preliminary studies on topol. similar isoreticular metal-org. framework-6 and -8 (IRMOF-6 and -8) having cyclobutylbenzene and naphthalene linkers, resp., gave approx. double and quadruple (2.0 wt.%) the uptake found for MOF-5 at room temp. and 10 bar.

        10d
        Design, Synthesis, Structure, and Gas (N2, Ar, CO2, CH4, and H2) Sorption Properties of Porous Metal-Organic Tetrahedral and Heterocuboidal Polyhedra
        Sudik, Andrea C.; Millward, Andrew R.; Ockwig, Nathan W.; Cote, Adrien P.; Kim, Jaheon; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2005), 127 (19), 7110-7118CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A strategy based on assembling metal ions and org. carboxylate links was applied for the design and synthesis of a new class of porous, truncated tetrahedral and heterocuboidal polyhedra, whose pore size and functionality can be systematically varied. The synthesis of this series of metal-org. polyhedra (MOPs) employs sulfate-capped O-centered Fe-carboxylate trimers, Fe3O(CO2)3(SO4)3, as rigid nodes sepd. by linear (Ph, biphenyl, terphenyl, and tetrahydropyrene) or trigonal (benzenetriphenyl) links to yield five highly cryst. polyhedra [NH2Me2]8[Fe12O4(SO4)12(link)x(py)12]·G (x = 6 for linear or 4 for trigonal, py = pyridine, G = guests). In this series, the size of each polyhedron was varied from 20.0 to 28.5 Å (on edge), and the corresponding pore diam. from 7.3 to 13.3 Å. Gas sorption isotherms were measured for three members of this series to reveal significant uptake of gases (N2, Ar, CO2, H2, CH4) and benzene and exhibit Type I sorption behavior that is indicative of permanent porosity. The apparent surface areas for these compds. range from 387 to 480 m2/g. Magnetic susceptibility studies indicate antiferromagnetic interactions between iron centers, and long-range coupling between clusters is assumed to be negligible.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXjtl2ntLg%253D&md5=654522c7c7f2351595cea3091c172cb1

        11a
        Hydrogen adsorption in the nanoporous metal-benzene dicarboxylate M(OH)(O2C-C6H4-CO2) (M = Al3+, Cr3+), MIL-53
        Ferey, Gerard; Latroche, Michel; Serre, Christian; Millange, Franck; Loiseau, Thierry; Percheron-Guegan, Annick
        Chemical Communications (Cambridge, United Kingdom) (2003), (24), 2976-2977CODEN: CHCOFS; ISSN:1359-7345. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        H adsorption was studied in the nanoporous metal-benzene dicarboxylate M(OH)(O2C-C6H4-CO2) (M = Al3+, Cr3+). These solids have H storage capacities of 3.8 and 3.1% resp. when loaded at 77 K under 1.6 MPa.

        11b
        Hysteretic Adsorption and Desorption of Hydrogen by Nanoporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Zhao, Xuebo; Xiao, Bo; Fletcher, Ashleigh J.; Thomas, K. Mark; Bradshaw, Darren; Rosseinsky, Matthew J.
        Science (Washington, DC, United States) (2004), 306 (5698), 1012-1015CODEN: SCIEAS; ISSN:0036-8075. (American Association for the Advancement of Science)
        Adsorption and desorption of hydrogen from nanoporous materials, such as activated C, is usually fully reversible. The authors prepd. nanoporous metal-org. framework materials with flexible linkers in which the pore openings, as characterized in the static structures, appear to be too small to allow H2 to pass. The authors observe hysteresis in their adsorption and desorption kinetics above the supercrit. temp. of H2 that reflects the dynamical opening of the windows between pores. This behavior would allow H2 to be adsorbed at high pressures but stored at lower pressures.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXptFyjtbc%253D&md5=42cbb6e1b708cd791929d4e89d328f95
        (c) Pan, L., Holson, D., Ciemnolonski, L. R., Heddy, R., and Li, J. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.2006 46 616 619
        [Crossref], Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (d) Dinca, M., Yu, A. F., and Long, J. R. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2006 128 8904 8913
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        11d
        Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks Incorporating 1,4-Benzeneditetrazolate: Syntheses, Structures, and Hydrogen Storage Properties
        Dinca, Mircea; Yu, Anta F.; Long, Jeffrey R.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (27), 8904-8913CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        The potential of tetrazolate-based ligands for forming metal-org. frameworks of utility in hydrogen storage is demonstrated using 1,4-benzeneditetrazolate (BDT2-) to generate robust, microporous materials. Reaction of H2BDT with MnCl2·4H2O and Mn(NO3)2·4H2O in N,N-diethylformamide (DEF) produces the two-dimensional framework solids Mn3(BDT)2Cl2(DEF)6 (1) and Mn4(BDT)3(NO3)2(DEF)6 (2), whereas reactions with hydrated salts of Mn2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+ in a mixt. of methanol and DMF afford the porous, three-dimensional framework solids Zn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3.5CH3OH (3), Mn3(BDT)3(DMF)4(H2O)2·3CH3OH·2H2O·DMF (4), Mn2(BDT)Cl2(DMF)2·1.5CH3OH·H2O (5), and Cu(BDT)(DMF)·CH3OH·0.25DMF (6). The method for desolvating such compds. can dramatically influence the ensuing gas sorption properties. When subjected to a mild evacuation procedure, compds. 3-6 exhibit permanent porosity, with BET surface areas in the range 200-640 m2/g. The desolvated forms of 3-5 store between 0.82 and 1.46% H2 at 77 K and 1 atm, with enthalpies of adsorption in the range 6.0-8.8 kJ/mol, among the highest so far reported for metal-org. frameworks. The desolvated form of 6 exhibits preferential adsorption of O2 over H2 and N2, showing promise for gas sepn. and purifn. applications.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XmtVSjtLg%253D&md5=c33a3b55e4ff31ac354ecbdd5b636120
      12. 12
        Adams, R. D., and Cotton, F. A. Catalysis by Di- and Polynuclear Metal Cluster Complexes; Wiley-VCH: New York, 1998.
        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
      13. 13
        (a) Fujita, M., Kwon, Y. J., Washizu, S., and Ogura, K. J. Am. Chem. Soc.1994 116 1151 1152
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13a
        Preparation, Clathration Ability, and Catalysis of a Two-Dimensional Square Network Material Composed of Cadmium(II) and 4,4'-Bipyridine
        Fujita, Makoto; Kwon, Yoon Jung; Washizu, Satoru; Ogura, Katsuyuki
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1994), 116 (3), 1151-2CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        A two-dimensional square network material {[Cd(4,4'-bpy)2](NO3)2}∞ (1) (bpy = bipyridine) was prepd. from Cd(NO3)2 and 4,4'-bpy. Having inner cavities surrounded by 4,4'-bpy units as shown by crystallog. anal., this material behaved like inorg. porous materials such as zeolites. Thus, the complex 1 easily formed the clathrate complex {[Cd(4,4'-bpy)2](NO3)2·2G}∞ (2,G = o-C6H4X2 or C6H5X, X = Br, Cl) with some arom. compds. and exhibited heterogeneous catalysis for cyanosilyation of aldehydes. X-ray diffraction study of 2 (G = o-C6H4Br2) showed a layered array of the two-dimensional network.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK2cXhsVGnt78%253D&md5=5af3fcd83e3709797b79fe9c9d22d26d
        (b) Kesanli, B., and Lin, W. B. Coord. Chem. Rev.2003 246 305 326
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13b
        Chiral porous coordination networks: rational design and applications in enantioselective processes
        Kesanli, Banu; Lin, Wenbin
        Coordination Chemistry Reviews (2003), 246 (1-2), 305-326CODEN: CCHRAM; ISSN:0010-8545. (Elsevier Science B.V.)
        A review is presented which provides a short discussion of recent progress in the synthesis and characterization of homochiral metal-org. coordination networks (MOCNs) and their applications in the areas of asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. Although chiral MOCNs can be constructed from achiral components, the resulting bulk solids tend to be racemic and are thus not useful for enantioselective processes. A couple of examples of homochiral solids built from achiral bridging ligands are presented along with more prevalent homochiral MOCNs built from chiral bridging ligands that are categorized based on their network dimensionality. Preliminary applications of these homochiral solids in asym. catalysis and chiral sepns. are also presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXpt1Gitrs%253D&md5=fc3129109058ea5a9d7f4716d5aed6b3
        (c) Rowsell, J. L. C., and Yaghi, O. M. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.2005 44 4670 4679
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13c
        Strategies for hydrogen storage in metal-organic frameworks
        Rowsell, Jesse L. C.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2005), 44 (30), 4670-4679CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Increased attention is being focused on metal-org. frameworks as candidates for hydrogen storage materials. This is a result of their many favorable attributes, such as high porosity, reproducible and facile syntheses, amenability to scale-up, and chem. modification for targeting desired properties. A discussion of several strategies aimed at improving hydrogen uptake in these materials is presented. These strategies include the optimization of pore size and adsorption energy by linker modification, impregnation, catenation, and the inclusion of open metal sites and lighter metals.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXnvVSqsrk%253D&md5=a5f3412f19f6b56b433d69a4e36ced31

        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13d
        Exceptional H2 Saturation Uptake in Microporous Metal-Organic Frameworks
        Wong-Foy, Antek G.; Matzger, Adam J.; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2006), 128 (11), 3494-3495CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Satn. H2 uptake in a series of microporous metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) has been measured at 77 K. Satn. pressures vary between 25 and 80 bar across the series, with MOF-177 showing the highest uptake on a gravimetric basis (7.5 wt %) and IRMOF-20 showing the highest uptake on a volumetric basis at 34 g/L. These results demonstrate that max. H2 storage capacity in MOFs correlates well to surface area, and that feasible volumetric uptakes can be realized even in highly porous materials.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhvVCjsr8%253D&md5=f6d94bff4ebfd39eedeec1e04573a2e4
        (e) Pan, L., Sander, M. B., Huang, X. Y., Li, J., Smith, M., Bittner, E., Bockrath, B., and Johnson, J. K. J. Am. Chem. Soc.2004 126 1308 1309
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        13e
        Microporous Metal Organic Materials: Promising Candidates as Sorbents for Hydrogen Storage
        Pan, Long; Sander, Michelle B.; Huang, Xiaoying; Li, Jing; Smith, Milton; Bittner, Edward; Bockrath, Bradley; Johnson, J. Karl
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2004), 126 (5), 1308-1309CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        Although extensive efforts have been made to improve H storage techniques, there is no viable storage technol. capable of meeting the DOE cost and performance targets. New materials with significantly improved H adsorption capability are needed. Microporous metal coordination materials (MMOMs) are promising sorbents for H adsorption. These materials possess phys. characteristics similar to those of single-walled C nanotubes and they also have a no. of advantages. A novel MMOM structure and its room-temp. H adsorption properties are presented.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXksFClsA%253D%253D&md5=f1b68f3ac25dc59c3ecc58c5300d5c9f
      14. 14
        (a) Hoskins, B. F., and Robson, R. J. Am. Chem. Soc.1990 112 1546 1554
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        14a
        Design and construction of a new class of scaffolding-like materials comprising infinite polymeric frameworks of 3D-linked molecular rods. A reappraisal of the zinc cyanide and cadmium cyanide structures and the synthesis and structure of the diamond-related frameworks [N(CH3)4][CuIZnII(CN)4] and CuI[4,4',4'',4'''-tetracyanotetraphenylmethane]BF4.xC6H5NO2
        Hoskins, B. F.; Robson, Richard
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (1990), 112 (4), 1546-54CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863.
        It is proposed that a new and potentially extensive class of scaffolding-like materials may be afforded by linking together centers with either a tetrahedral or an octahedral array of valences by rodlike connecting units. Some simple general principles concerning the design and construction of these frameworks are presented together with reasons for expecting them to show unusual and useful properties. Two of the simplest conceivable systems of this type are isomorphous Zn(CN)2 and Cd(CN)2 whose structures were reexamd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction, confirming the earlier description based on powder diffraction data of 2 interpenetrating diamond-related frameworks: cubic, space group P‾43m, Z = 2; with a 5.9002(9) Å (Zn(CN)2) and 6.301(1) Å (Cd(CN)2); 2 unique metal centers, 1 surrounded tetrahedrally by 4C and the other by 4N donors; MCNM rods linear; Zn-C 1.923(6), Zn-N 2.037(5), Cd-C 2.099(5), Cd-N 2.196(4), C-N 1.150(5) Å in Zn(CN)2, and 1.162(5) Å in Cd(CN)2. The interpenetration of sep. frameworks demonstrated in these archetypal structures is likely to be a major concern in future studies of more complex scaffolding materials. [N(CH3)4][CuZn(CN)4] was deliberately designed to demonstrate one conceivable way of preventing interpenetration; it is cubic, space group F‾43m, with A 11.609(3) Å; Z = 4. The structure contains a single diamond-related framework with alternating tetrahedral Cu(I) and Zn(II) centers and linear rods that are very likely of the type CuCNZn with bond distances Cu-C 1.877(8) and Zn-N 2.069(15) Å, Z(CH3)4+ ions occupy half the adamantane cavities generated by the framework, the remaining cavities being vacant. CuI[4,4',4'',4'''-tetracyanotetraphenylmethane]BF4·xC6H5NO2 (x ≥ 7.7) represents the first attempt to generate an infinite 3-dimensional framework with rods of some complexity. It is tetragonal, space group I‾4m2, with a 13.620(2) and c 22.642(2) Å; Z = 2. The structure contains a diamond-related cationic framework with C·C6H4·CN·Cu rods of length 8.856(2) Å. The framework is tetragonally elongated along the c axis apparently as a result of nonbonded interactions between the 8 ortho-H atoms around the methane C centers. There is no interpenetration. The framework generates very large adamantane-like cavities occupied by disordered C6H5NO2 (at least 7.7 mols. per Cu) together with BF4- ions. The crystals undergo ready anion exchange. The material is unusual in that approx. two thirds by vol. of what is undoubtedly a crystal is effectively liq. The results provide confidence that a wide range of scaffolding-like solids should prove accessible.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaK3cXovVOjtw%253D%253D&md5=2a9efabcd93072e8668a50199c51320c
        (b) Robson, R. J. Chem. Soc., Dalton Trans.2000 3735 3744
        [Crossref], Google Scholar

        (a) Janiak, C. Dalton Trans.2003 3 2781 2804

        15b
        Crystal Engineering of NLO Materials Based on Metal-Organic Coordination Networks
        Evans, Owen R.; Lin, Wenbin
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2002), 35 (7), 511-522CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Crystal engineering, the ability to predict and control the packing of mol. building units in the solid state, has attracted much attention over the past three decades owing to its potential exploitation for the synthesis of technol. important materials. The authors present here the development of crystal-engineering strategies toward the synthesis of noncentrosym. infinite coordination networks for use as 2nd-order nonlinear optical (NLO) materials. Work performed mainly in the authors' lab. demonstrated that noncentrosym. solids based on infinite networks can be rationally synthesized by combining unsym. bridging ligands and metal centers with well-defined coordination geometries. Specifically, coordination networks based on 3-dimensional diamondoid and 2-dimensional grid structures can be successfully engineered with a high degree of probability and predictability to crystallize in noncentrosym. space groups. The authors have also included noncentrosym. solids based on 1-dimensional chains and related helical structures for comparison.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XivFOisbs%253D&md5=64ac5ff5434793e9e28fcb1b460fb049
        (c) Ockwig, N. W., Delgado-Friedrichs, O., O’Keeffe, M., and Yaghi, O. M. Acc. Chem. Res.2005 38 176 182
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15c
        Reticular Chemistry: Occurrence and Taxonomy of Nets and Grammar for the Design of Frameworks
        Ockwig, Nathan W.; Delgado-Friedrichs, Olaf; O'Keeffe, Michael; Yaghi, Omar M.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (3), 176-182CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        The structures of all 1127 three-periodic extended metal-org. frameworks (MOFs) reported in the Cambridge Structure Database were analyzed, and their underlying topol. was detd. It is remarkable that among the almost infinite no. of net topologies that are available for MOFs to adopt, only a handful of nets are actually obsd. The discovery of this inversion between expected and obsd. nets led the authors to deduce a system of classification taxonomy for interpreting and rationalizing known MOF structures, as well as those that will be made in future. The origin of this inversion is attributed to the different modes with which MOF synthesis was approached. Specifically, three levels of complexity are defined that embody rules grammar for the design of MOFs and other extended structures. This system accounts for the present proliferation of MOF structures of high symmetry nets, but more importantly, it provides the basis for designing a building block that codes for a specific structure and, indeed, only that structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2MXksFSgsg%253D%253D&md5=13530d98a4733672738db281372887ae
        (d) Batten, S. R., and Robson, R. Angew. Chem., Int. Ed.1998 37 1460 1494
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        15d
        Interpenetrating Nets: Ordered, Periodic Entanglement
        Batten Stuart R; Robson Richard
        Angewandte Chemie (International ed. in English) (1998), 37 (11), 1460-1494 ISSN:.
        Independent one-, two-, and even three-dimensional nets interpenetrate each other in many solid-state structures of polymeric, hydrogen-bonded nets and coordination polymers. For example, the interpenetration of the adamantane units of two diamondlike nets is shown on the right. A detailed and systematic examination of many interpenetrating nets of this kind is made, and implications for crystal engineering are discussed.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        15e
        Metal carboxylates with open architectures
        Rao, C. N. R.; Natarajan, Srinivasan; Vaidhyanathan, R.
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (12), 1466-1496CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. The field of inorg. open-framework materials is dominated by aluminosilicates and phosphates. The metal carboxylates have emerged as an important family in the last few years. This family includes not only mono- and dicarboxylates of transition, rare-earth, and main-group metals, but also a variety of hybrid structures. Some of the carboxylates possess novel adsorption and magnetic properties. Dicarboxylates and related species provide an effective means of designing novel hybrid structures with porous and other properties. In some of these structures, the dicarboxylate acts as a linker between two inorg. units. Hybrid nanocomposites are also of particular note, for example, cadmium oxalate host lattices that can accommodate extended alkali-metal halide structures. This review discusses the synthesis, structure, and properties of various types of open-framework metal carboxylates.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXisl2hsbo%253D&md5=32807fb667da7932d3bd2ace7e18f208

        Functional porous coordination polymers
        Kitagawa, Susumu; Kitaura, Ryo; Noro, Shin-ichiro
        Angewandte Chemie, International Edition (2004), 43 (18), 2334-2375CODEN: ACIEF5; ISSN:1433-7851. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A review. Discussion concs. on three aspects of coordination polymers: (1) the use of crystal engineering to construct porous frameworks from connectors and linkers (nano-space engineering), (2) characterizing and cataloging the porous properties by functions for storage, exchange, sepn., etc., and (3) the next generation of porous functions based on dynamic crystal transformations caused by guest mols. or phys. stimuli. The authors' aim is to present the state of the art chem. and physics of and in the micropores of porous coordination polymers.

        Controllable Assembly of Metal-Directed Coordination Polymers under Diverse Conditions: A Case Study of the MII-H3tma/Bpt Mixed-Ligand System
        Du, Miao; Jiang, Xiu-Juan; Zhao, Xiao-Jun
        Inorganic Chemistry (2006), 45 (10), 3998-4006CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        New metal-org. polymeric complexes, {[Co(bpt)(Htma)(H2O)3]·2.25H2O}n (1), [Co(bpt)(Htma)(H2O)]n (2), [Ni(bpt)(Htma)(H2O)]n (3), [Zn(bpt)2(H2tma)2]·6H2O (4), {[Cd(bpt)(Htma)(H2O)]·(EtOH)(H2O)1.5}n (5), and {[Cd(bpt)(Htma)(H2O)2]·5.5H2O}n (6), were prepd. from soln. reactions of 4-amino-3,5-bis(4-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt) and trimesic acid (H3tma) with different metal salts under diverse conditions. All these compds. were structurally detd. by x-ray single-crystal diffraction, and the bulk new materials were further identified by x-ray powder diffraction. Complexes 1 and 6 show 1-dimensional zigzag or linear Htma-bridged polymeric chains, with the terminal bpt ligands as pendants, which are extended to 2-dimensional H-bonded arrays with 4.82 or (6,3) network topol. Coordination polymers 2 and 3, in which the 2-dimensional corrugated metal-org. frameworks make the interdigitated 3-dimensional packing, are isostructural. Complex 4 has a mononuclear structure, and its subunits are H-bonded to each other to give a 2-dimensional gridlike net. For complex 5, the CdII centers are linked by bpt/Htma ligands to form a 2-dimensional (4,4) coordination layer, and these layers are interdigitated in pairs. Notably, secondary noncovalent forces, such as H bonds, play an important role in extending and stabilizing these structural topologies. Distinct products were obtained for CoII (1 and 2) and CdII (5 and 6) under ambient or hydrothermal conditions; however, for NiII and ZnII, single products, 3 and 4, are generated. The thermal stabilities of 1-6 were studied by TGA of mass loss. The desorption/adsorption properties of the porous material 5 are also discussed. Solid-state luminescent spectra of the ZnII and CdII complexes, 4-6, indicate intense fluorescent emissions at ca. 380 nm.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XjsFWqurc%253D&md5=c0f4dcdacc47022cb682b4018c2f3fbb
        (c) Paz, F. A. A., and Klinowski, J. Inorg. Chem.2004 43 3882 3893
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16c
        Two- and Three-Dimensional Cadmium-Organic Frameworks with Trimesic Acid and 4,4'-Trimethylenedipyridine
        Paz, Filipe A. Almeida; Klinowski, Jacek
        Inorganic Chemistry (2004), 43 (13), 3882-3893CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Three novel Cd-org. frameworks built-up from 1,3,5-benzenetricarboxylate anions (HXBTCx-3) and 4,4'-trimethylenedipyridine (TMD) were hydrothermally synthesized, and characterized using single-crystal x-ray diffraction, thermoanal. measurements, elemental anal., and IR and Raman spectroscopies: [Cd(HBTC)(TMD)2]·8.5H2O (I), [Cd(HBTC)(TMD)(H2O)]·4.5H2O (II), and [Cd2(BTC)(TMD)2(NO3)]·3H2O (III), with structures I and II being isolated as a mixt. of crystals. Structure I contains an undulating infinite two-dimensional [Cd(HBTC)(TMD)2] framework, with a (4,4) topol. and rectangular pores, ∼3.4 × 11.0 Å in cross-section, distributed in a herringbone manner. The crystal structure of I was obtained by parallel packing of this 2-dimensional framework in an [ABAB···] fashion. Compd. II has a porous 3-dimensional diamondoid framework with channels running in several directions of the unit cell, which allows 2-fold interpenetration to occur. The most prominent channels are distributed in a brick-wall fashion along the c axis and have a cross-section of ∼3.2 × 13.2 Å. Structure III can be seen as the three-dimensional assembly of binuclear secondary building units (SBU), which leads to a compact, neutral, and coordinatively bonded eight-connected framework, [Cd2(BTC)(TMD)2(NO3)], exhibiting an unusual 36422 topol. The increased flexibility of the TMD ligands (brought about by the three methylene groups between the two 4-pyridyl rings) can lead, for the same reactive system, to a large variety of crystal architectures.

        A nanoscale supramol. hexagon, [Cu6(5-NO2-bdc)6(DMSO)6(MeOH)3(H2O)9] (1), and its supramol. isomeric polymeric chain structure, [Cu2(DMSO)2(MeOH)(H2O)3]n (2), were prepd. from self-assembly of H25-NO2-bdc (5-nitrobenzene-1,3-dicarboxylic acid) and Cu(II) cations. The hexagon is neutral and sol. and has outer and inner diams. of 3.1 and 0.8 nm, resp.

        16e
        Syntheses and crystal structures of five cadmium(II) complexes derived from 4-aminobenzoic acid
        Wang, Ruihu; Hong, Maochun; Luo, Junhua; Cao, Rong; Shi, Qian; Weng, Jiabao
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2002), (11), 2904-2912CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Five cadmium(II) complexes, [CdClL·H2O]n (1), [CdBrL·H2O]n (2), CdI2(HL)2 (3), {[Cd(dca)2(HL)2]·2H2O}n (dca- = dicyanamide) (4), and (H2L)2[CdCl4(H2O)2] (5), were synthesized by the reaction between 4-aminobenzoic acid (HL) and Cd2+. In 1 and 2, L- serves as a tridentate ligand and bridges six-coordinate CdII centers to form [CdII-L]n chains; halide anions link adjacent chains into two-dimensional layers. Complex 3 is a typical metallic carboxylic acid synthon. In 3, HL acts as a monodentate ligand coordinating to CdII through the nitrogen atom, and the head-to-tail hydrogen bonds of carboxylic groups result in a zigzag chain. The weak Cd...I interactions between adjacent chains extend the zigzag chain-like structure into a two-dimensional structure. Complex 4 consists of [Cd(dca)2(HL)2]n chains and free water mols. The twelve-membered rings formed by water mols. and carboxylic groups through hydrogen bonds link the adjacent chains to yield a two-dimensional layer. Complex 5 consists of discrete [CdCl4(H2O)2]2- anions and H2L+ org. cations, which are linked by intermol. hydrogen-bonding interactions to form a three-dimensional structure.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD38XotlCitLk%253D&md5=53e9dab04fc9a7de4fb37b7aa683a2ec
        (f) Biradha, K. CrystEngComm2003 5 374 384
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16f
        Crystal engineering: from weak hydrogen bonds to co-ordination bonds
        Biradha, Kumar
        CrystEngComm (2003), 5 (), 374-384CODEN: CRECF4; ISSN:1466-8033. (Royal Society of Chemistry)
        A review. This article highlights the importance of crystal engineering in designing functional materials. Various rational design strategies are discussed for controlling the mol. architectures of the materials using C-H···O, C-H···π, O-H···O, N-H···O and O-H···N H bonds and coordination bonds. The results described here show the role of guest mols. in templating the isomeric network structures with one set of mol. components. In particular, the materials that are designed based on strong H bonds and coordination bonds exhibited zeolite like and clay like properties.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XkvVeluro%253D&md5=8047fc99fba4ae3512ba2124005db3c6
        (g) Varughese, S., and Pedireddi, V. R. Chem.—Eur. J.2006 12 1597 1609
        [Crossref], [PubMed], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16g
        A competitive molecular recognition study: syntheses and analysis of supramolecular assemblies of 3,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid and its bromo derivative with some N-donor compounds
        Varughese, Sunil; Pedireddi, Venkateswara Rao
        Chemistry--A European Journal (2006), 12 (6), 1597-1609CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        A mol. recognition study of 3,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid (1) and its bromo deriv. 4-bromo-3,5-dihydroxybenzoic acid (2) with the N-donor compds. 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene (bpyee), 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane (bpyea), and 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy) is reported. Thus, the syntheses and structural anal. of mol. adducts 1a-1c (1 with bpyee, bpyea, and bpy, resp.) and 2a-2c (2 with bpyee, bpyea, and bpy, resp.) are discussed. In all these adducts, recognition between the constituents is established through either O-H...N and/or O-H...N/C-H...O pairwise hydrogen bonds. In all the adducts both OH and COOH functional groups available on 1 and 2 interact with the N-donor compds., except in 2a, in which only COOH (COO-) is involved in the recognition process. The COOH moieties in 1a, 1b, and 2b form only single O-H...N hydrogen bonds, whereas in 1c and 2c, they form pairwise O-H...N/C-H...O hydrogen bonds. In addn., subtle differences in the recognition patterns resulted in the formation of cyclic networks of different dimensions. In fact, only 1c forms a four-mol. cyclic moiety, as was already documented in the literature for this kind of assemblies. All complexes have been characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. The supramol. architectures are quite elegant and simple, with stacking of sheets in all adducts, but a rather complex network with a threefold interpenetration pattern was found in 2c.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD28XhvFKksb0%253D&md5=ee3ae4654c57a4e1ca533a30ad88d4dd
        (h) Wang, J., Lin, Z. J., Ou, Y. C., Yang, N. L., Zhang, Y. H., and Tong, M. L. Inorg. Chem.2008 47 190 199
        [ACS Full Text ], [CAS], Google Scholar
        16h
        Hydrothermal Synthesis, Structures, and Photoluminescent Properties of Benzenepentacarboxylate Bridged Networks Incorporating Zinc(II)-Hydroxide Clusters or Zinc(II)-Carboxylate Layers
        Wang, Jing; Lin, Zhuojia; Ou, Yong-Cong; Yang, Nai-Liang; Zhang, Yue-Hua; Tong, Ming-Liang
        Inorganic Chemistry (Washington, DC, United States) (2008), 47 (1), 190-199CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        The first coordination compds. of partially or wholly deprotonated 1,2,3,4,5-benzenepentacarboxylic acid (H5L) were synthesized in the presence or absence of auxiliary 2,2'-bipyridine (2,2'-bpy) and 1,10-phenanthroline (phen) ligands, and their crystal structures and photoluminescent properties were characterized. Their formulas are [Zn6(μ3-OH)2(L)2(H2O)6]n (1), [Zn5(μ3-OH)2(HL)2(2,2'-bpy)2]n (2), [Zn2(HL)(phen)2(H2O)2]n (3), and [Zn5(L)2(phen)4(H2O)3]n·2nH2O (4). Both 1 and 2 are three-dimensional (3D) zinc(II)-hydroxide cluster based coordination frameworks. Complex 1 contains distorted chair-like hexanuclear Zn6(μ3-OH)2 cluster units as secondary building blocks. Each Zn6(μ3-OH)2 unit connects six others through the three-connected nodes of L5- ligands into a 3D rigid and condensed coordination network, whereas in 2 each pentanuclear Zn5(μ3-OH)2 unit connects the other six ones through the three-connected [HL]4- nodes into a 3D network in the simple cubic packing mode. Complex 3 has two-dimensional (2D) Zn(II)-carboxylate supramol. layers constructed from a one-dimensional (1D) coordination chain structure by hydrogen bonds of the water and μ5-[HL]4- bridges, whereas 4 has 2D coordination layers composed of Zn(II) and μ8-L5- bridges. The adjacent coordination assemblies in 3 and 4 are further extended by hydrogen bonds and π···π interactions into 3D supramol. architectures. Complexes 1-4 are photoluminescent active materials, and their photofluorescent properties are closely related to their intrinsic structure arrangements.

        Bottom up Synthesis That Does Not Start at the Bottom: Quadruple Covalent Cross-Linking of Nanoscale Faceted Polyhedra
        Perry, John J., IV; Kravtsov, Victor Ch.; McManus, Gregory J.; Zaworotko, Michael J.
        Journal of the American Chemical Society (2007), 129 (33), 10076-10077CODEN: JACSAT; ISSN:0002-7863. (American Chemical Society)
        A novel 3-dimensional metal-org. coordination polymer constructed from hollow, spherical, nanometer-sized mol. faceted polyhedra and a flexible tetracarboxylate ligand designed to simultaneously assemble and cross-link these nanoballs in situ was synthesized and structurally characterized. The crystal structure involves 2-fold interpenetration with each framework exhibiting pores of dimensions which vary from <1 nm to just over 2.5 nm.

        Ligand Design in Multimetallic Architectures: Six Lessons Learned
        Steel, Peter J.
        Accounts of Chemical Research (2005), 38 (4), 243-250CODEN: ACHRE4; ISSN:0001-4842. (American Chemical Society)
        A review. Metallosupramol. chem. involves the use of combinations of org. ligands and metals for the construction of both discrete and polymeric aggregates. This Account describes some lessons that the authors learned about aspects of ligand design in the authors' work in this area. Specifically, the authors recommend the incorporation of a diverse range of heterocyclic rings and arene cores within the ligands, as well as attention to symmetry considerations, and offer suggestions for the introduction of chirality and flexibility within the ligands and the exploitation of other weak interactions to assist self-assembly processes.

        Dendrimers with Alternating Amine and Ether Generations
        Pan, Yijun; Ford, Warren T.
        Journal of Organic Chemistry (1999), 64 (23), 8588-8593CODEN: JOCEAH; ISSN:0022-3263. (American Chemical Society)
        Dendrimers having alternating aryl benzyl ether and tertiary amine generations and up to 16 bis(2-methoxyethyl)amine end groups and four internal tertiary amines were synthesized by sequential etherification, amidation of secondary amines, and LiAlH4 redn. to tertiary amines. At 2.8 mM, the dendrimer increases the soly. of pyrene in water 30-fold, and the solvated pyrene is not aggregated.

        A Simultaneous Reduction, Substitution, and Self-Assembly Reaction under Hydrothermal Conditions Afforded the First Diiodopyridine Copper(I) Coordination Polymer
        Lu, Jack Y.; Babb, Amy M.
        Inorganic Chemistry (2002), 41 (6), 1339-1341CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        A simultaneous redn. of Cu(II) to Cu(I) by pyridinecarboxylate and the substitution of carboxylato groups by iodo nucleophiles in a self-assembly process under hydrothermal conditions afforded a new I-inclusion coordination polymer [CuI(C5H3NI2)·1/2I2] 1. [IC5H3NCOOH] 2 and revealed that the catalytic properties of Cu ions in redox and substitution reactions under hydrothermal conditions are attractive.         Spek, A. L. J. Appl. Crystallogr.2003 36 7 13
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        24
        Single-crystal structure validation with the program PLATON
        Spek, A. L.
        Journal of Applied Crystallography (2003), 36 (1), 7-13CODEN: JACGAR; ISSN:0021-8898. (Blackwell Munksgaard)
        The results of a single-crystal structure detn. when in CIF format can now be validated routinely by automatic procedures. In this way, many errors in published papers can be avoided. The validation software generates a set of ALERTS detailing issues to be addressed by the experimenter, author, referee and publication journal. Validation was pioneered by the IUCr journal Acta Crystallographica Section C and is currently std. procedure for structures submitted for publication in all IUCr journals. The implementation of validation procedures by other journals is in progress. This paper describes the concepts of validation and the classes of checks that are carried out by the program PLATON as part of the IUCr check CIF facility. PLATON validation can be run at any stage of the structure refinement, independent of the structure detn. package used, and is recommended for use as a routine tool during or at least at the completion of every structure detn. Two examples are discussed where proper validation procedures could have avoided the publication of incorrect structures that had serious consequences for the chem. involved.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD3sXltlChtw%253D%253D&md5=0a85de2407551632bb287508534904e2

        Google Scholar
        There is no corresponding record for this reference.
        (b) Lines, M. E. J. Chem. Phys.1971 55 2977 2984
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        25b
        Orbital angular momentum in the theory of paramagnetic clusters
        Lines, M. E.
        Journal of Chemical Physics (1971), 55 (6), 2977-84CODEN: JCPSA6; ISSN:0021-9606.
        The statistical theory of paramagnetic clusters described in the literature to date is largely restricted to "spin-only" magnetism for which orbital angular momentum is quenched, or enters the calcns. only as a trivially modified g factor. This paper discusses the extension of the theory to magnetic ions for which large unquenched orbital angular momentum is present, rendering the conventional approach completely inoperative. A theory is developed in detail for cobaltous cluster complexes, the cobaltous ion generally being one of the more difficult of the 3d transition metal ions to describe statistically. A preamble into relevant crystal-field theory is followed by the development of a statistical theory valid, to a good approxn., over the entire temp. range. Numerical results are presented to indicate the sep. effects of spin-orbital redn., and inter- as well as intracluster exchange. The full theory is also compared numerically with the results of simpler, but less adequate, approxns. to demonstrate the penalty in accuracy paid for algebraically less onerous calcns. The theoretical principles involved are readily extendable for use with other magnetic ions (e.g., ferrous) for which unquenched orbital angular momentum plays an essential role.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADyaE3MXltFCitb8%253D&md5=6c31abc468ce65a76e0610f0a8c2b355

        [CAS], Google Scholar
        26a
        Synthesis, structure and magnetism of homologous series of polycrystalline cobalt alkane mono- and dicarboxylate soaps
        Rueff, Jean-Michel; Masciocchi, Norberto; Rabu, Pierre; Sironi, Angelo; Skoulios, Antoine
        Chemistry - A European Journal (2002), 8 (8), 1813-1820CODEN: CEUJED; ISSN:0947-6539. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Carboxylate-bridged chain complexes of CoII (the diaquacobalt(II) mono- and α,ω-dialkanoates) form two homologous series of layered compds. which were fully characterized both structurally and magnetically. The crystal structures of two selected members, [Co[CH3(CH2)10COO]2(H2O)2] (I) and [Co[CH3(CH2)18COO]2(H2O)2] (II), were solved by x-ray powder diffraction and selected-area electron diffraction methods, and refined by the Rietveld technique. Crystal data: I, monoclinic, space group P21/a; a 9.688(1), b 7.5495(9), c 37.281(5) Å, β 96.70(3)°, Z = 4; and II, monoclinic, space group P21/a; a 9.7260(7), b 7.5477(7), c 57.53(1) Å, β 94.66(4)°, Z = 4, resp. Their isomorphous structures contain layers of octahedral diaquacobalt(II) ions bonded to two chem. inequivalent alkanoates, one chelating and one bridging two Co atoms ∼6.3 Å apart, thus confirming the rare anti-anti conformation mode of the μ-RCOO groups recently proposed for diaquacobalt(II) α,ω-dodecanedioate. Extensive magnetic characterization allowed estn. of the feeble antiferromagnetic coupling, which is weaker in the mono- than in the dialkanoate series.

        26b
        Structure and magnetism of a polycrystalline transition metal soap - CoII[OOC(CH2)10COO](H2O)2
        Rueff, Jean-Michel; Masciocchi, Norberto; Rabu, Pierre; Sironi, Angelo; Skoulios, Antoine
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2001), (11), 2843-2848CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Diaquacobalt(II) n-dodecane-α,ω-dioate (2) was synthesized by metathesis of the corresponding K soap 1 and was fully characterized by chem. and spectroscopic anal. The crystal structure of 2 was established by x-ray powder diffraction techniques combined with electron diffraction expts. It crystallizes in a monoclinic cell P21/a; a 9.6558(8), b 7.4793(6), c 19.8936(2) Å, β 95.648(9)°, V = 1429.7(3) Å3; Z = 2 and consists of stacked layers of Co(II) ions connected by carboxylato bridges, thus forming chains that extend along the α axis. These layers are sepd. by alkyl chains arranged quasi-perpendicularly to the polar sheets. Structure anal. reveals a rare anti-anti conformation of the Co-OCO-Co fragments, which probably is responsible for the weak antiferromagnetism of the CoII chains. The exchange coupling const. between the magnetic centers was estd. as J = -2.08 K.

        Copper(II) and cobalt(II) dicarboxylate-based layered magnets: influence of π electron ligands on the long range magnetic ordering
        Rabu, P.; Rueff, J. M.; Huang, Z. L.; Angelov, S.; Souletie, J.; Drillon, M.
        Polyhedron (2001), 20 (11-14), 1677-1685CODEN: PLYHDE; ISSN:0277-5387. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        The authors discuss the structure and magnetic properties of multilayer compds. M2(OH)2A·zH2O, where M=Co(II) or Cu(II) and A is a dicarboxylate anion. They consist of metal hydroxide-based layers connected through difunctional species (A), which, depending on their nature (alkane-, alkene-dioate or terephthalate) act as pillars or electronic connectors. Either metamagnetism or ferromagnetism is obsd., with a huge coercive field of 5.9 T at 4 K in the case of the cobalt(II) hydroxyterephthalate. The aim is to show that π electron species connecting ferromagnetic layers may induce unexpected magnetic properties. High-frequency EPR expts. (95 GHz) and magnetic measurements are reported, giving information on the local structure and the exchange couplings.

        Crystal structure and magnetic properties of dicarboxylate-bridged linear chain Mn(II) complexes
        Kim, J.; Lim, J. M.; Suh, M. C.; Yun, H.
        Polyhedron (2001), 20 (15-16), 1947-1951CODEN: PLYHDE; ISSN:0277-5387. (Elsevier Science Ltd.)
        Two Mn(II) complexes, [Mn(mtm)(MeOH)2(H2O)]n (1) and [Mn2(mtm)2(2,2'-bipy)2]n (2) (bipy = bipyridine, mtm = [bis(methylthio)methylene]malonate) were synthesized and characterized by x-ray crystallog. The structure of 1 consists of octahedral Mn(II) species which are extended by carboxylate bridges in syn-anti fashion along the c-axis. Chains of 1 are assocd. by H bonding among coordinating H2O and MeOH mols. and carboxylate O atoms, forming two-dimensional structures. The crystallog. asym. unit of 2 comprises two [Mn(2,2'-bipy)(mtm)] units in which Mn(II) atoms are bridged by μ2-oxygens from carboxylate to form Mn2O2 rhombus. The dimeric units are linked doubly by 2nd carboxylates in syn-anti fashion, resulting in a chain structure. The antiferromagnetic coupling of Mn(II) ions in 1 (-0.2 cm-1) and 2 (-1.57 cm-1) was detd. from variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility data at 2-300 K. New linear chain complexes of manganese(II), [Mn(mtm)(MeOH)2(H2O)]n and [Mn2(mtm)2(2,2'-bipy)2]n were synthesized by using the dicarboxylate ligand. X-ray structure anal. shows that Mn(II) ions are bridged by carboxylate with the syn-anti mode. The antiferromagnetic interactions between the high spin Mn(II) ions of these complexes were detd. from variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility data.

        (b) Xue, D. X., Zhang, W. X., and Chen, X. M. J. Mol. Struct.2008 877 36 43
        [Crossref], [CAS], Google Scholar
        29b
        Synthesis, structures, and physical properties of metal flexible dicarboxylate frameworks with dipyridyl coligand
        Xue, Dong-Xu; Zhang, Wei-Xiong; Chen, Xiao-Ming
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2008), 877 (1-3), 36-43CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Five new metal-org. frameworks [Zn(bct)(4,4'-bipy)] (1) (H2bct = 2,5-bis(carboxymethylmercapto)-1,3,4-thiadiazole acid; 4,4'-bipy = 4,4'-bipyridine) [Cd(bct)(H2O)(4,4'-bipy)0.5] (2), as well as three isostructural compds., [M(bct)(H2O)(4,4'-bipy)] [M = Zn (3), Mn (4), Co (5)], were obtained by reactions of the corresponding metal salts with a flexible dicarboxylic acid, H2bct and 4,4'-bipy, and their structures were detd. by single-crystal x-ray diffraction. 1 Features a two-dimensional (2-D) layer structure consisting of 1-dimensional (1-D) Zn-bct chain and 4,4'-bipy, while 2 has 2-dimensional rectangular-grid layers with the bct carboxylate groups adopting similar coordination mode in 1, but different conformations in ligating Cd(II) ions, which is inserted into 4,4'-bipy. Addnl., there exist π-π stacking and intermol. H-bonding interactions in 1 and 2, resp., forming 3-dimensional supramol. structures. In 3-5, undulating 2-dimensional metal-bct layer structures are formed with another coordination mode of bct carboxylate groups, which are further extended by 4,4'-bipy into 3-dimensional structures. The luminescence properties of 1-3 were studied. Low-temp. magnetic data indicate weakly antiferromagnetic exchange in 4 and 5.
        >> More from SciFinder ®

        29c
        Synthesis and characterization of two linear trinuclear complexes [M3(CH3COO)6(H2O)(phen)2]·H2O (M = Co, Mn)
        Wang, Mei; Ma, Cheng-Bing; Wang, Hui-Sheng; Chen, Chang-Neng; Liu, Qiu-Tian
        Journal of Molecular Structure (2008), 873 (1-3), 94-100CODEN: JMOSB4; ISSN:0022-2860. (Elsevier B.V.)
        Two linear trinuclear compds., [Co3(CH3COO)6(H2O)(phen)2]·H2O (1) and [Mn3(CH3COO)6(H2O)(phen)2]·H2O (2, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), were synthesized and characterized by single crystal x-ray diffraction, IR spectroscopy, thermal anal. and magnetic measurements. The x-ray analyses of 1 and 2 show that the two compds. have the same coordination environment but different central metal ions (Co(II) and Mn(II), resp.). The structures of 1 and 2 both consist of a trinuclear cobalt/manganese unit coordinated by two terminal phen groups, one H2O on the central Co(II)/Mn(II) and six CH3COO- groups featuring four kinds of bonding modes. The magnetic measurements of the two complexes reveal overall antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the metal ions.

        29e
        Synthesis, structure and magnetic properties of a series of novel isophthalate-bridged manganese(II) polymers with double-layer or double-chain structures
        Ma, Chengbing; Chen, Changneng; Liu, Qiutian; Chen, Feng; Liao, Daizheng; Li, Licun; Sun, Licheng
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2004), (16), 3316-3325CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Four isophthalate-bridged Mn(II) coordination polymers, [Mn4L4(H2O)2(Him)4]n (1), [MnL(Him)2]n (2), [MnL(dpe)]n·0.5n(dpe)·nH2O (3) and [Mn2L2(bpy)2]n (4) [L = isophthalate, Him = imidazole, bpy = 2,2'-bipyridine and dpe = (E)-1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethene], were rationally synthesized and characterized by single-crystal x-ray structure detns. and magnetic studies. Both 1 and 3 are two-dimensional (2D) double-layer polymers. In 1, novel Mn4 entities are linked by L ligands, while 3 is made of [MnL]n parallel double chains cross-linked by the μ-dpe ligands. Both 2 and 4 are 1-dimensional (1D) double-chain polymers, where 2 is composed of [MnL]n parallel double chains capped by the Him ligands, while 4 is made of [Mn2L2]n helical double chains capped by the chelating bpy ligands. Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility measurements revealed weak antiferromagnetic exchange interactions between the adjacent MnII ions of the four coordination polymers. The data of 2-4 were fitted to the homonuclear alternating chain model to give magnetic coupling parameters of J1 = -0.71(4) to -1.01(3) cm-1 and J2 = -0.02(2) to -0.46(2) cm-1. In the case of 1, the fitting of magnetic data considering only the interactions within the Mn4 moiety led to J = -2.17(1) cm-1 and zJ' = -0.01(5) cm-1, using a combination of a dimeric model and a mean mol. field approxn. model.
        >> More from SciFinder ®
        https://chemport.cas.org/services/resolver?origin=ACS&resolution=options&coi=1%3ACAS%3A528%3ADC%252BD2cXns1Smsro%253D&md5=310df4eaf4b95bfbac159c39715e7c7b

        Molecular, one- and two-dimensional systems built from manganese(II) and phthalate/diimine ligands: Syntheses, crystal structures and magnetic properties
        Ma, Chengbing; Wang, Wenguo; Zhang, Xiaofeng; Chen, Changneng; Liu, Qiutian; Zhu, Hongping; Liao, Daizheng; Li, Licun
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2004), (17), 3522-3532CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH & Co. KGaA)
        Several new MnII compds., [Mn2(Hphth)2(phen)4](Hphth)2·2H2O (1; H2phth = phthalic acid, phen = 1,10-phenanthroline), [Mn2(Hphth)2(phen)4](ClO4)2·2H2O (2), [Mn4(phth)4(phen)4(H2O)4]·2EtOH (3), {[Mn4(phth)2(phen)8](PF6)4}2 (4), [Mn4(phth)2(bipy)8](ClO4)4·2EtOH (5; bipy = 2,2'-bipyridine), [Mn(phth)(bipy)(H2O)2]n (6), and [Mn(phth)(pyz)(H2O)2]n (7; pyz = pyrazine), were synthesized by treatment of the appropriate Mn2+ salt and H2phth with different diimine ligands. They were characterized by x-ray diffraction and show a variety of nuclearities, ranging from dinuclear (1 and 2) to tetranuclear (3-5), and dimensionalities, ranging from a 1-dimensional chain (6) to a 2-dimensional layer network (7), in which the phthalates act as primary bridging ligands coordinating to Mn atoms through their carboxylate groups in various bonding modes. Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility measurements reveal weak antiferromagnetic coupling interactions in 1, 3, 4 and 6.

        Structural analyses and magnetic properties of 3D coordination polymeric networks of nickel(II) maleate and manganese(II) adipate with the flexible 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane Ligand
        Mukherjee, Partha Sarathi; Konar, Sanjit; Zangrando, Ennio; Mallah, Talal; Ribas, Joan; Chaudhuri, Nirmalendu Ray
        Inorganic Chemistry (2003), 42 (8), 2695-2703CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Two novel inorg.-org. hybrid 3-dimensional extended networks of Ni(II) and Mn(II) having mol. formulas [(maleate)2Ni3(bpe)4(H2O)4](NO3)2·H2O (1) and [(adipate)Mn(bpe)] (2) (bpe = 1, 2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethane), resp., were synthesized and characterized by single-crystal x-ray diffraction studies and low-temp. (300-2 K) magnetic measurements. Crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group C2/c, with chem. formula C56H62N10Ni3O19, a 30.955(4), b 12.705(3), c 17.058(5) Å, β 117.26(2)°, and Z = 4. Crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P‾1, with chem. formula C18H20MnN2O4, a 8.492(2), b 9.444(2), c 11.533(3) Å, α 97.19(1), β 94.64(1), γ 105.02(1)°, and Z = 2. The structure detn. reveals for both a 3-dimensional network. Contains two crystallog. independent Ni(II) ions in different octahedral environments. Ni(1) lies on an inversion center, and its coordination environment comprises two chelating maleate anions and two bpe N donors, while the Ni(2) ion is surrounded by meridionally disposed three bpe N atoms, two H2O mols., and one O donor from the dicarboxylate anion. Of the three crystallog. independent bpe ligand, one presents an anti and the others a gauche conformation and the corresponding N-to-N distances are 9.344, 6.543, and 6.187 Å. Variable-temp. magnetic susceptibility measurement of 1 reveals the existence of a dominant ferromagnetic interaction within the mol. Is composed of Mn2 dimer units linked by adipate anions to form corrugated 2-dimensional sheets which, on interconnection through bpe (anti conformation, N-to-N distance of 9.391 Å), produces an interpenetrated 3-dimensional α-Po-related type net. Complex 2 reveals to be antiferromagnetic fitting data using a dimeric Mn(II) model that considers negligible magnetic transmission through the C skeleton of adipate and the bpe pathway.

        Polynuclear MnII complexes with chloroacetate bridge - syntheses, structure, and magnetic properties
        Fernandez, Gema; Corbella, Montserrat; Mahia, Jose; Maestro, Miguel A.
        European Journal of Inorganic Chemistry (2002), (9), 2502-2510CODEN: EJICFO; ISSN:1434-1948. (Wiley-VCH Verlag GmbH)
        Three new polynuclear MnII complexes with chloroacetate bridges were obtained and characterized by x-ray diffraction: [Mn3(μ-ClCH2COO)6(bpy)2] (1), [Mn2(μ-ClCH2COO)2(phen)4](ClO4)2 (2), and [Mn(μ-ClCH2COO)2(phen)]n (3). The Mn...Mn distance for 1 (3.624 Å) is smaller than for 2 (4.613 Å) and 3 (4.530 Å); this is in agreement with the no. of carboxylate bridges. The three compds. show a weak antiferromagnetic coupling. The J values are -3.82 cm-1 for 1, -0.85 cm-1 for 3, and no coupling was obsd. for 2. Each compd. showed a characteristic EPR spectrum at 4 K. Simulation of these spectra could be obtained with D = -0.16 cm-1 and E = -0.015 cm-1 for compd. 1, and D = -0.045 cm-1 and E = -0.004 cm-1 for compd. 2.

        29i
        Synthesis, Structural Characterization (X-ray and EXAFS), and Magnetic Properties of Polynuclear Manganese(II) Complexes with Chlorobenzoato Bridges
        Albela, Belen; Corbella, Montserrat; Ribas, Joan; Castro, Isabel; Sletten, Jorunn; Stoeckli-Evans, Helen
        Inorganic Chemistry (1998), 37 (4), 788-798CODEN: INOCAJ; ISSN:0020-1669. (American Chemical Society)
        Three different types of polynuclear MnII complexes with carboxylate bridges were obtained from the reaction of Mn(RCOO)2 (R = 2-ClPh, 3-ClPh, 4-ClPh, Ph) with 2,2'-bipyridine (bpy). These were [Mn2(μ-RCOO)2(bpy)4](ClO4)2 (1-4), [Mn3(μ-RCOO)6(bpy)2] (R = 2-ClPh, 3-ClPh (5, 6)), [Mn3(μ-RCOO)6(2,2'-Me2-bpy)2] (R = 2-ClPh, 3-ClPh, 4-ClPh (7-9)) and 1-dimensional [Mn(μ-RCOO)2(bpy)]n (R = 3-ClPh, 4-ClPh (10, 11)). 4 Crystallizes in the triclinic system, space group P‾1 with a 9.1886(10), b 11.6135(9), c 13.595(2) Å, α 66.225(13), β 84.073(12), γ 88.593(10)°, Z = 1. 10·H2O crystallizes in the monoclinic system, space group C2/c with a 26.376(5), b 12.404(3), c 7.095(1) Å, β 96.10(3)°, Z = 4. The other complexes were characterized by XANES and EXAFS studies, by comparison with analogous complexes of known x-ray crystal structure. The Mn···Mn distances in the dinuclear complexes and in the infinite chains were similar (av. 4.5 Å) and longer than for the trinuclear complexes (av. 3.6 Å). This is in agreement with the no. of carboxylate bridges: two in the 1st case and three for the trinuclear complexes. All the polynuclear complexes shown very weak antiferromagnetic coupling (J between -0.7 and -3.22 cm-1). So, at low temps. more than one spin state may be populated and many possible transitions may be expected in the EPR spectra; each series shows a similar spectrum, which is different from the others.
